skill.name: when-detecting-fake-code-use-theater-detection
skill.description:
Detects non-functional "theater" code that appears complete but doesn't actually work.
Use this skill to identify code that looks correct in static analysis but fails during execution,
preventing fake implementations from reaching production. Scans for suspicious patterns,
validates actual functionality, and reports findings with recommendations.

security_audit.summary: This is a code quality testing skill that scans codebases for non-functional "theater" code patterns. It uses grep and Node.js for static analysis and test execution validation. All operations are local filesystem operations within the scanned project directory with no network calls, credential access, or code execution beyond the scanned codebase itself.

content.value_statement: Fake code that appears complete but doesn't work can reach production and cause failures. This skill systematically identifies theater code through pattern scanning, execution validation, and behavioral analysis to prevent non-functional implementations from shipping.
actual_capabilities: Scans codebases for theater patterns including empty catch blocks, no-op functions, and always-pass tests
Analyzes implementations for meaningful logic using AST parsing and control flow analysis
Validates suspected theater code through actual execution and behavior testing
Categorizes issues by severity (critical, high, medium, low) with confidence scores
Generates comprehensive reports with prioritized remediation recommendations
Provides automated fixes for simple patterns and manual fix guides for complex cases
limitations: Cannot detect all forms of subtle theater code that passes execution tests
May produce false positives requiring manual review of flagged files
Execution validation requires test framework and may crash on dependent code
Automated fixes are conservative and require manual review for complex cases

best_practices: Run theater detection before merging AI-generated code into main branch
Set appropriate confidence threshold to balance detection with false positive rate
Always review automated fixes before committing to ensure they match intended behavior
Integrate theater detection into CI/CD pipeline as a quality gate
anti_patterns: Merging AI-generated code without theater detection checks
Ignoring low-confidence theater indicators as they may indicate partial theater code
Applying automated fixes without reviewing the generated fix guide
Running detection only on new code without auditing existing codebase

faq.question: What code patterns does this skill detect?
faq.answer: Empty catch blocks, no-op functions, always-pass tests, trivial returns, mock code in production, and TODO/FIXME markers indicating incomplete work.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my codebase?
faq.answer: Only when using the --auto-fix flag. It creates backups first and provides a fix guide for manual review of complex cases.

faq.question: Does this skill require external network access?
faq.answer: No. All operations are local filesystem scanning and execution within the project directory using Node.js and grep.

faq.question: How accurate is the detection?
faq.answer: Detection accuracy depends on patterns matched. False positives are possible; adjust confidence threshold or review flagged files manually.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes. Use --fail-on-critical flag to fail builds with critical theater code detected. Works with GitHub Actions and pre-commit hooks.

faq.question: What is the difference from a linter?
faq.answer: Theaters go beyond syntax issues. This skill validates actual runtime behavior and catches code that appears correct but does not implement intended functionality.
